introduction.p:
In an earlier section, we found that coservative forces are special when it comes to work, viz., work by these forces are independent of the path between the initial and final positions. Such work can be written purely in terms of initial and final positions, denoted by U_i and U_f, respectively.
W_{if}^{\text{conservative}} = U_i - U_f.
Now, we ask: what will happen if only conservative forces are acting on a body? Replacing work in the work energy theorem will give us guidance to the answer.
K_f - K_i = W_{if}^{\text{net}} = \sum W_{if}^{\text{conservative}} = \sum U_i - \sum U_f,
where \sum U_i is the sum of all potential energies, U , evaluated at instant t_i , and similarly for \sum U_f .
Rearranging terms in this equation we get
K_i + \sum U_i = K_f + \sum U_f.
That is, if all the forces are conservative, then the combination \left(K + \sum U \right) is conserved during the motion.

We call the combination K + \sum U energy (sometimes, mechanical energy), and denoted it by symbol E.
E = K + \sum U.
Equation can now be expressed rather compactly as follows. If all forces acting on the body are conservative forces, then energy cannot change. This is called the principle of conservation of energy.
E_i = E_f.\ \ \ \ (\text{all forces conservative})

example.title: The Energy of a Skier Going Down a Slope - Ignoring Drag and Kinetic Friction Forces

statement.p: A skier starts near the top of a hill. His speed at a point on the slope that is 50\text{ m} above the sea level is 5.0\text{ m/s} .
What will be his speed when he reaches a point that is 35\text{ m} above the sea level, assuming you can neglect the effect of drag and kinetic fricion forces on the skier?

solution.p: Ignoring Drag and Kinetic Friction forces, the forces on the skier are (1) Weight and (2) Normal. Normal force will do no work since, at each instant, it is perpendicular to the displacement. And weight is a conservative firce. Therefore, energy of the skier is conserved.

Hence, by equating energy of the skier at the two instants in the problem statement we get
\dfrac{1}{2}mv_f^2 + mgy_f = \dfrac{1}{2}mv_i^2 + mgy_i.
The mass m cancels out. Solving for v_f we get
v_f = \sqrt{ v_i^2 + 2g(y_i - y_f) }.
Now, we put in the numbers.
v_f = \sqrt{ 5.0^2 + 2\times 9.81\times ( 50 - 35) } = 17.9\text{ m/s}.
Note the requirement of no drag or friction was critical for us to use conservation of energy!

example.title: Energy Conservation of a Block Attached to a Spring in a Horizontal Motion

statement.p: A block of mass 300 grams is attached to a spring of spring constant 100 N/m. The other end of the spring is attached to a support while the block rests on a smooth horizontal table and can slide freely without any friction as illustrated in . The block is pushed horizontally till the spring compresses by 12 cm, and then the block is released from rest.
(a) How much potential energy was stored in the block-spring-support system when the block was just released?
(b) Determine the speed of the block when it crosses the point when the spring is neither compressed nor stretched.
(c) Determine the speed of the block when it has traveled a distance of 20 cm from where it was released.

solution.title: a
solution.p:
Using the formula for the spring potential energy we get
U_a = \dfrac{1}{2}kx^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 100 \times 0.12^2 = 0.72\text{ J}.

solution.title: b
solution.p: When the block crosses the equilibrium point, x = 0. That means potential energy is zero at this point. Let v_b be the speed when passing through the equilibrium point (see ).

When the block was releases at the initial instant in part (a), all the energy was potential energy. Therefore, we get the following equation when we apply energy conservation.
\dfrac{1}{2} m v_b^2 + 0 = 0 + U_a.
Therefore,
v_b = \sqrt{ \dfrac{2U_a}{m} } = \sqrt{ \dfrac{2 \times 0.72}{0.3} } = 2.2\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: c
solution.p:
20 cm from the place the motion began, the block would be 8 cm from the equilibrium, because it will go 12 cm to equilibrium and then stretch another 8 cm. Let's call this x_c and the speed there as v_c. Therefore, the energy conservation will give
\dfrac{1}{2} m v_c^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}kx_c^2 = 0 + U_a.
Solving for v_c gives
v_c = \sqrt{ \dfrac{2}{m} \left(U_a - \dfrac{1}{2}kx_c^2 \right) }.
Now, we put the numbers.
\dfrac{1}{2}kx_c^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 100 \times 0.08^2 = 0.32\text{ J}.
Therefore,
v_c = \sqrt{\dfrac{2}{0.3}\left(0.72 - 0.32 \right) } = 1.63 \text{ m/s}.

example.title: Escape Velocity and Energy to Launch a Spacecraft from Earth

statement.p: A spacecraft of mass m is launched vertically upward from the surface of the Earth (radius R_E) with initial speed v_0. Assume only gravitation of Earth acts on the spacecraft. (a) Find an expression of maximum distance r_\text{max}, the spacecraft will go before coming down, assuming v_0 is not sufficient to escape the gravity of Earth? (b) What is the minimum value of v_0 at which spacecraft will escape the gravity of Earth? (c) If spacecraft has mass 100\text{ kg}, how much energy would be needed to escape the gravity of Earth?

solution.title: a

sidebyside.p: Since only gravitational force is acting, energy of the spacecraft after launch will be conserved. At the maximum distance point, speed of the craft will be zero.

solution.p:
Thus, we get
\frac{1}{2}mv_0^2 - G_N \frac{M_E m}{R_E} = 0 - G_N \frac{M_E m}{r_\text{max}}.
Also, note that g of Earth also relates to its mass and radius by
g = G_N \frac{M_E }{R_E^2}.
Using this in Eq. we get
\frac{1}{2}mv_0^2 - mgR_E = - m g R_E^2 \frac{1}{r_\text{max}}.
This can be solved for r_\text{max}.
r_\text{max} = \frac{2gR_E^2}{ 2gR_E - v_0^2 }.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
To escape means r_\text{max} = \infty. From Eq. , we see that it will occur when
2gR_E - v_0^2 = 0.
Lets denote this initial speed by v_\text{es}.
v_\text{es} = \sqrt{2gR_E}.
With g=9.81\text{ m/s}^2, R_E=6.37\times10^6\text{ m}, we get
v_\text{es} = 1.12 \times 10^{4}\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: c
solution.p:
The energy needed will be the kinetic energy at the launch site.
E = \frac{1}{2}m v_\text{es}^2 = m g R_E.
Now, we use numerical values to get
E = 6.25\times 10^{9}\text{ J}.

exercise.title: Energy Conservation in a Plane Pendulum

p.p: A 200-g steel ball is tied to a 2-m massless string and hung from the ceiling to make a pendulum. The ball is released from rest at a point that makes a 30^{\circ} angle with the vertical direction. Find speed of the ball at the following points in its motion:
(b) at an angle of 20^{\circ} with the vertical,

hint.p: Use energy conservation. For energy of pendulum bob, you need height from the bottom, h = l - l \, \cos\, \theta .

solution.title: a

sidebyside.p:
The figure here shows the height h of the bob from the zero potential energy reference. From the adjacent side of the triangle and the length of the string, we get
h = l - l \, \cos\, \theta.

solution.p:
At initial instant, the energy of the pendulum bob is all potential energy since it is at rest.
E = \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgh = 0 + 0.2\times 9.81\times 2\left(1-\cos\,30^\circ \right) = 0.5257\text{ J}.

(a) Let v_a stand for the speed when the bob is at the bottom of the swing. At this instant h=0. Using the conservation of energy we get the following equation.
\dfrac{1}{2}mv_a^2 + 0 = 0.5257\text{ J}.
Therefore,
v_a = \sqrt{ \dfrac{2\times 0.5257}{0.2} } = 2.29 \text{ m/s}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
Let v_b stand for the speed when the bob is at the place when the pendulum angle is 20^\circ. Using the conservation of energy we get the following equation.
\dfrac{1}{2}mv_b^2 + mgh_b = E,
where E = 0.5257\text{ J} and
h_b = l \left(1 - \cos\, 20^\circ \right) = 0.1206\text{ m}.
Solving for v_b .
v_b = \sqrt{ \dfrac{2}{m} \left( E - mg h_b\right)}.
Numerically, we have
v_b = \sqrt{\dfrac{2}{0.2} (0.5257 - 0.2 \times 9.81 \times 0.1206 ) } = 1.7\text{ m/s}.

exercise.title: Energy Conservation of a Block Attached to a Spring in a Vertical Motion

sidebyside.p: A block of mass 300 grams is attached at the end of a massless spring of spring constant 10 N/m. The other end of the spring is attached to the ceiling and the mass is brought to rest. Let us mark this point as O. Suppose, this point is taken to be the zero of the gravitational potential energy of the block. The zero of the spring potential energy is the point where the spring is neither stretched nor compressed, which is a distance d above O.

statement.p: The mass hangs freely and the spring is in a stretched state. The block is then pulled downward by another 15 cm and released from rest. This will be the lowest point in the motion of the block since we are releasing the block from rest.
(a) How far above point O is the zero of the spring potential energy? That is, find d.
(b) What is the energy of the block at the instant the block is at the lowest point?
(c) What is the speed of the block at the instant the block returns to O?

hint.p: (a) Balance forces at O. (b) Add two potential energies. (c) Use conservation of energy. (d) Use conervation of energy.

solution.title: a
solution.p:
We just need to find the stretching that took place when we hung the block. Let this distance be d. Balancing gravitational and spring forces when the block is at O gives
k d = mg.
Therefore,
d = \dfrac{mg}{k} = \dfrac{0.3\times 9.81}{10} = 0.294 \text{ m}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
When the block is at the lowest point, it has only potential energy, which is a sum of the spring and gravitational potential energies. The net deformation of the spring is \Delta l = 0.294 \text{ m} + 0.15 \text{ m} = 0.444\text{ m}. This will give
U_\text{sp} = \dfrac{1}{2}k (\Delta l)^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 10 \times 0.444^2 = 0.99\text{ J}.
The gravitational potential energy will be with respect to O. Since this point is below O, the gravitaional potential energy will be negative.
U_\text{gr} = mgh = 0.3\times 9.81\times (-0.15) = - 0.44\text{ J}.
Therefore, the total energy at this point is
E_\text{bottom} = U_\text{sp} + U_\text{gr} = 0.55 \text{ J}.

solution.title: c
solution.p:
Energy is conserved here. When the block returns to O, it has zero gravitational potential energy, but it still has spring potential energy for the stretch d found in (a) above.
U_\text{sp,at O} = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 10 \times 0.294^2 = 0.432 \text{ J}.
Applyig energy conservation between this point and the lowest point of motion in part (b) gives the following for speed v when at O.
\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 + U_\text{sp,at O} + 0 = E_\text{bottom}.
This gives
v = \sqrt{ \dfrac{ 2(0.55 - 0.432) }{0.3} } = 0.89 \text{ m/s}.

exercise.title: Energy Conservation of a Block Attached to a Spring in Motion on Inclined Surface

sidebyside.p: A block of mass 500\text{ grams} is attached to a spring. The other end of the spring is attached to a support while the mass rests on a smooth frictionless surface inclined at angle of 30^{\circ}. Initially, when the block is resting, the spring is compressed by 2 \text{ cm}.

statement.p: The block is pushed along the surface till the spring compresses by additional 10 \text{ cm} and then released from rest. After that, the block executes a back and forth motion along the inclined surface.
(a) What is the spring constant of the spring?

(b) (i) How much potential energy was stored in the block-spring-support system at the instant the block was released? (ii) Taking this point to be the zero of the gravitational potential energy, what is the total energy of the block when it is at this location?
(c) Determine the speed of the block when it crosses the point when the spring is neither compressed nor stretched.
(d) Determine the position of the block where it just comes to rest on its way up the incline. Express the distance of this point on the incline from the point it was released.

solution.title: a

sidebyside.p:
We balance forces along the incline when the block is not yet pushed. The component of weight along the incline is balanced by the spring force from compression by 2\text{ cm}.
kx \amp = mg\sin\theta \amp = 0.5\times 9.81\times \sin\,30^\circ = 2.45\text{ N}.

solution.p:
Therefore,
k = \dfrac{2.45\text{ N}}{0.02\text{ m}} = 123\text{ N/m}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
(i) Spring potential energy with \Delta l = 0.12\text{ m} gives the answer. Let's refer to this point as b.
U_\text{sp,b} = \dfrac{1}{2}kx^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 122.6 \times 0.12^2 = 0.883\text{ J}.

(ii) Based on the choice of zero of gravitational potential energy, we have
U_\text{gr,b} = 0
Therefore, potential energy of the block when it is at this location is
U_\text{b} = 0.883+0 = 0.883\text{ J}.
Since the block is at rest here, K_\text{b} = 0. Therefore, total energy of the block is
E_\text{b} = 0.883\text{ J}.

solution.title: c

sidebyside.p:
At this point U_\text{sp,c} = 0, but we have gravitaional potential energy nonzero.
U_\text{gr,b} = mgh_c,
where h_c is the vertical height of this point from the point where we choose the zero of the gravitational potential energy. The two points are separated by 0.12\text{ m} along the incline. That means
h_c = 0.12\,\sin\,30^\circ = 0.06\text{ m}.

solution.p:
Therefore,
U_\text{gr,c} = mgh_c = 0.5\times 9.81\times 0.06 = 0.294\text{ J}.
Using conservation of energy between (b) and this point we get
\dfrac{1}{2}mv_c^2 + 0.294 = 0.883.
This gives
v_c = \sqrt{ 2( 0.883 - 0.294 )/0.5} = 1.54\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: d
solution.p:
Let x denote the distance on the incline the block moved from the point it was released. This would mean the spring would be extended by
\Delta l = x - 0.12,
and height h_d of this point is
h_d = x\,\sin\,30^{\circ} = \dfrac{x}{2}.
Now, setting up conservation of energy with total energy 0.883\text{ J} gives
\dfrac{1}{2}k\left( x - 0.12\right)^2 + m g \dfrac{x}{2} = 0.883.
Solving this, keeping the positive root gives
x = 0.20\text{ m}.

exercise.title: Speed to Launch Satellite for Circular Orbit About Earth

sidebyside.p: A satellite of mass m is to be placed in a circular orbit of radius 2 R_E, where R_E is the radius of the Earth. With what speed with respect to the fixed center of the Earth should the satellite be launched from a point on the equator of the Earth?

hint.p: First find the speed when in the circular orbit by using Newton's equation for uniform circular motion. Then, find the energy when in the circular orbit. Finally, use energy conservation to find the speed of launch.

solution.p: Strategy: Let v_0 be the speed of launch and v_c the speed when the satellite is in the circular orbit. We will first obtain v_c from Newton's equation of motion for the circular motion. Then, we will get energy of the satellite when in the orbit. After that, energy conservation between energy when in circular orbit and immediately after lauch will give us a condition from which we will obtain v_0.

The equation of motion of the circular orbit for uniform circular motion gives
m\,\dfrac{v_c^2}{ 2R_E } = G \dfrac{M_E m}{ \left(2 R_E \right)^2 }.
Solve this for \dfrac{1}{2}mv_c^2 to get
\dfrac{1}{2} m v_c^2 = G \dfrac{M_E m}{ 4 R_E }.
To this we add the potential energy to get the energy E_c when the satellite is in the circular orbit.
E_c = \dfrac{1}{2} m v_c^2 - G \dfrac{M_E m}{ 2 R_E } = - G \dfrac{M_E m}{ 4 R_E }.
The energy E_0 at the instant after launch is
E_0 = \dfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 - G \dfrac{M_E m}{ R_E }.
Equating E_0 and E_c we get
\dfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 - G \dfrac{M_E m}{ R_E } = - G \dfrac{M_E m}{ 4 R_E }.
Therefore,
v_0 = \sqrt{ \dfrac{3 G M_E}{2 R_E } } \approx 6.8\text{ km/s}.
